change.item: Encoded in EAD by Jodi Boyle

repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.abstract: This collection documents Equal Justice USA's efforts to abolish capital punishment and reform the criminal justice system nationwide. It focuses in particular on the organization's campaign for a nationwide moratorium against the death penalty in 2000, as well as records leading up to and resulting from this campaign.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed in 2024 by Mattie Klein and Maggie Zehr.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: This page may contain links to digital objects. Access to these images and the technical capacity to download them does not imply permission for re-use. Digital objects may be used freely for personal reference use, referred to, or linked to from other web sites.
Researchers do not have permission to publish or disseminate material from these collections without permission from an archivist and/or the copyright holder.

The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming to the laws of copyright. Some materials in these collections may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) and/or by the copyright or neighboring-rights laws of other nations. More information about U.S. Copyright is provided by the Copyright Office. Additionally, re-use may be restricted by terms of University Libraries gift or purchase agreements, donor restrictions, privacy and publicity rights, licensing and trademarks.
The Department of Special Collections and Archives is eager to hear from any copyright owners who are not properly identified so that appropriate information may be provided in the future.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: All items in this collection were transferred to the University Libraries, M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives by Equal Justice USA Executive Director Shari Silberstein in 2008 and 2016. Silberstein packed up additional records in 2021 and they were then donated by the organization in 2022.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Equal Justice USA is a national organization that seeks to create a fair, effective criminal justice system. Its campaign to end capital punishment, particularly its nationwide campaign for a moratorium during the year 2000, is the group's largest and longest-standing program. Equal Justice USA also frequently partnered with other organizations, both national and local, on both sides of the political aisle, including the Quixote Center. These partnerships aim to dismantle oppressive systems and protect historically underserved citizens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of materials discussing Equal Justice USA's efforts to abolish capital punishment and reform the U.S. criminal justice system. Included are subject files, clippings, mailings to Equal Justice USA supporters, other correspondence, organizational projects and programs, state files, death penalty moratorium resolutions, legislative resources, annual reports, newsletters, some case files, and audio/video resources.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Equal Justice USA Records, 1975-2021. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Equal Justice USA Records).

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The archivist transferred several monographs: 10.10 is World Day. Abolish the Death Penalty. It's a Better World Without It. 10 October 2012 World Day Against the Death Penalty, report by the World Coalition Against the Death Penalty; Death Sentences: 34 Classic Short Stories About the Death Penalty by Chekhov, Tolstoy, Poe, Dunbar, Balzac, Twain, Kafka, Dickens and More Great Writers edited by Susan Ives; Irreversible Error: Recommended Reforms for Preventing and Correcting Errors in the Administration of Capital Punishment, a Report of the Constitution Project's Death Penalty Committee; Mandatory Justice: The Death Penalty Revisited by The Constitution Project; Moratorium 2000: Abolition of the Death Penalty at the 54th UN Commission on Human Rights edited by Hands Off Cain; No Justice: No Victory. The Death Penalty in Texas by Susan Lee Campbell Solar; Shall Suffer Death by A.J. Bannister; Teaching Abolition: 10 October 2009 World Day Against the Death Penalty, report by the World Coalition Against the Death Penalty; Towards Abolition: The Law and Politics of the Death Penalty, 1998 Report edited by Hands Off Cain; Truth Be Told: Life Lessons From Death Row, Correspondence of Agnes and Richard Nields; Twisted Truth: A True Account of the Struggle for Justice of a Death Row Inmate by Wendy Schmid-Eastwood; Waiting to Die: A Death Row Missioner Researches Death by Virginia Walden Hogue to the book division of Special Collections. They will be catalogued and included in the University Library Catalog.
